<question>



Should politicians be allowed to endorse commercial products?



What are the pro's and con's of this and what could its effects be?



</question>



<answer from>



oldnodd
Member since: 31 May 2008
Total points: 5595 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



no  - leaves them open to manipulation



</answer>



<answer from>



ham0423
Member since: 04 November 2008
Total points: 111 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



It wouldn't surprise me after this campaign to see this happen.  I don't think that politicians should endorse or not endorse any product or company though.  I think this would create a conflict of interest as to when a company is bribing a political figure under the false pretenses of endorsement.  I think this would create a potentially hazardous situation for all parties involved.  This would make lobbying much easier for the companies though.



</answer>



<answer from>



maillady...
Member since: 13 July 2008
Total points: 3659 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



no.  The reasons are obvious.



</answer>

Someone told me today that because of the way the Electoral College system works, McCain would become president !!



Seems strange but maybe its true.
Does anyone know?



</question>

<question from>



Spawnee
Member since: 19 October 2006
Total points: 7198 (Level 5)



</question from>



<question>



If we had 646 independent MP's in the UK, how would get to be PM and how is that decision made?



</question>



<answer from>



Liam
Member since: 27 November 2007
Total points: 3479 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



I've often wondered that. I don't think anyone knows - not that they need to, because that would never happen.



</answer>



<answer from>



Capt Jack
Member since: 10 May 2006
Total points: 4054 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Pretty much in a similar way to the way a political party selects its leader, people would put themselves forward and there would be a vote.



Exactly how the vote would be administered, given there would be no party structure to do it, would be difficult: it would probably have to be done by house of commons staff.



The difference being that in some political parties, all members would be eligible to vote, not just the MPs.



</answer>

<answer from>



crosssti...
Member since: 26 February 2006
Total points: 16849 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



It does if you know the demographics here in Indiana.  The main counties that went blue were Marion, Lake, and Monroe Counties.  These are some of the biggest population centers--Marion County is Indianapolis, Lake County is Gary, Hammond, and several other highly populated towns, and Monroe County is home to Indiana University.  Many of the other counties are predominately rural, so even if they go Republican, that's not a lot of votes.



Source(s):



Indiana Politaholic for almost 40 years.



</answer>



<answer from>



Gary B
Member since: 16 May 2008
Total points: 13388 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Diabetes



</answer from>



<answer>



ALl of the counties with large populations (Lake, Marion etc) went for Obama, but the REST of the state's smaller counties went for McCain.



Lake County is a subburb of South Chicago, and is predominantly African-American, Marion County, the state capital, has a high percentage of African-Americans, as does St Joseph County (South Bend).  Tippecanoe, Monroe, and Vigo counties are college towns, with predominantly young Americans.



The rest of the state is predominantly rural white Republicans.



</answer>

Beautiful Chaos

</question from>



<question>



Congress is who actually decides laws and makes changes in the US, correct?



If I remember correctly, isn't it Congress who writes up a bill, votes on it, sends it to the President, and if he agrees, it becomes a law.  If he vetoes it, it goes back to Congress. Don't they vote AGAIN on it and if there is a 2/3 vote for it, it becomes law anyway?



</question>



<answer from>



David L
Member since: 27 February 2007
Total points: 3461 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Pretty much.



</answer>



<answer from>



bucks4ev...
Member since: 19 July 2007
Total points: 670 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes you're right. But keep in mind that the President may propose legislation as well.



</answer>



<answer from>



Christopher K
Member since: 19 May 2008
Total points: 9885 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



A President can sign or veto a law; Congress can override the veto, but only if (a) they want to and (b) they have the votes.



</answer>

PEOPLE ARE DYING ALL OVER THE WORLD, AND PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATES HAVE BUDGETS TOPPING ONE BILLION DOLLARS.  Hate is irrelevant, my friend.  People are going to be people.  Which means they are going to sin.  Hate is inherently a part of this process, but really, this all comes from the God-given right we all have to make our own choices and form our own opinions........and boy, do we a have a ****-ton of each or what?  People suck, and most of them make shitty decisions, every day.  This definitely includes me!



But do you know what gives me a glimmer of hope in the midst of this huge shitstorm of lies, commercialism, war, pandemic diseases, and utter immorality we all must live in during this day and age?



It is this...........I remember, I have learned, and I most importantly and truly feel in my heart that this very night is the beginning of the End of Days, and I am so looking forward to the day when I will not have to walk into a booth, and vote for someone whom I feel is "the lesser of two evils"........I am not bashing either of them, however, I truly believe that the state that the world is in now is not able to be rectified.  It's over, and soon money, or status, stock markets, gas prices, what degree or job you have.....none of it is going to matter.  The solution to humanities largest problems (see first paragraph) is coming soon.......He is our ray of hope, and those that have faith and goodness in thier hearts......well, we won't have to worry about standing 3 hours in line to vote, or money or power, or greed, we won't have to worry about hate, or lies, or gas prices, and we won't have to worry about our children growing up in a world where they constantly have to look over thier shoulders, a world where 7 year olds die alone from gunshot wounds in the backs of SUV's, or a world where one man can order the deaths of 33 million people because he does not like thier religion.  The fate of this world is, and has been, beyond any politician for hundreds of years.  My hope for this world, the solution, is that it is time for our true heavenly leader to start fulfilling prophecies.
Starting tonight.



</answer>

<question>



What is it when someone says they are Independant in political terms?



</question>



<answer from>



ed9455
Member since: 15 June 2006
Total points: 5837 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



You are now living in the Socialist States of America !
Turn in your weapons and surrender your property for redistribution



</answer>



<answer from>



dlk
Member since: 18 January 2006
Total points: 25781 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



They believe beyond the Democratic and Republican philosophy.  They support any candidate who is closest to their beliefs on how this Country should be run, not by what party that candidate belongs to.  Thus the term "Independent"



</answer>



<answer from>



betty boop
Member since: 02 September 2006
Total points: 5773 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Just means they don't follow a particular party.  I am Independent - some stuff Dems say I agree with and some stuff Reps say I agree with.  It also means that both parties will be calling you all the time to get you to sway their way.  You will also receive so much junk mail from these parties you could have saved a whole forest.



</answer>



<answer from>



Christopher G
Member since: 05 July 2008
Total points: 2508 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



It means that they are not registered as either a Democrat or Republican, or possibly any smaller party as well. Generally, they are politically moderate with views common to both sides of the aisle.



</answer>



<answer from>



bengal
Member since: 08 April 2007
Total points: 213 (Level 1)



</answer from>

<question>



John Hanson was the 1st black president, why is everybody so up in arms saying Obama is?



http://africanamerica.org/groupee/forums...



</question>



<additional details>



Just face it people, Obama isnt the 1st, John Hanson was still recognized as the 1st president, and 1st black president of the U.S.



</additional details>



<answer from>



dawn666a...
Member since: 06 October 2007
Total points: 13450 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>

<asker's comment>

<answer from>



paganmom
Member since: 30 August 2006
Total points: 12032 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



He wasn't the president of the United States, he was the first president  of the US in Congress Assembled under the Articles of Confederation.  Which basically meant he was the president of Congress..not the United States. He did not have power like the President had.  In fact Congress had very little power at that time because the US was not really the US yet, there was no Constitution.  They were a Confederation of independent states, not a country under one government.



Oh..I forgot to mention, he wasn't black.  That was a misconception given when someone assumed that his father, an indentured servent, was a chattel slave.  His father was not black and was not of African desent.



Source(s):



~BA in History



</answer>



<answer from>

Member since: 08 July 2006
Total points: 31231 (Level 7)

<answer>



Just because we set a moral standard doesn't mean we live up to it all the time.  Remember, when the Founding Fathers set up the U.S., they intended "all men" to be all white landowning males.  Abigail Adams tried to get John Adams to include, women, but it didn't happen until 1920.  Blacks didn't get the right to vote until after the Civil War.  There was a lot of suspicion and hatred among groups, and there still is among some.  I think we're gradually getting away from it, but you can't turn away from it on a dime.



</answer>

"DO YOU UNDERSTAND THESE RIGHTS THAT YOU DO NOT HAVE?"



3. You have the right to be mercilessly riddled with about three cases of police bullets, when they asked you, "Do you have a firearm?" and you bent down and drew out your Saturday Nite Special.

Therefore, a DERRINGER, owned by the late suspect, becomes an M-60 by the time that the ambulance arrives, and by the time the body reaches the morgue, it has attained the the size, shape, and mass of a WW II Howitzer.

cause yeterday i saw his son beau and daugther ashley and then he was carrying a little girl and there was like other 2 little girls. so i was wondering who they were?



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



Joe Biden has three children, two sons from his first marriage and a daughter to Jill Biden.  Joe Biden's first wife and infant daughter were killed in an automobile accident five years prior to meeting and marrying Jill.  Both of his sons were in the accident as well and survived.  All those very young ones are his grandchildren.



</answer>

I never thought in my lifetime that I would be so moved, so involved, or so inspired by an election. Last night's presidential results, have given this country a new hope. My hope is that people will see this victory as the beginning of a nation without racial, religious, or financial divide. I feel the urge to answer the call. I believe that African Americans needed to see Obama win to give them the incentive to open their minds that this country values and accepts them. I believe that those living below the poverty line needed to see the victory of a president that recognizes their hard work and sacrifices. I believe that young people needed to see that yes, you can accomplish great feats through hard work and determination. I believe that those people living with the fear of having a president who is not white, needed to see that this nation is a nation of color and diversity. <answer from>



msvena
Member since: 25 October 2008
Total points: 100 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Some people are angry because their candidate lost.  It's been this way in several of the more recent presidential elections.  It has nothing to do with Obama's race.  In 2004, many Kerry supporters were just as angry that Kerry didn't win.



To "123,"  President-Elect Obama did not win because he is black.  According to YAHOO!, Obama has over 64 million popular votes.  The vast majority of those votes were cast by voters who are NOT black.  While it is true that the majority of African-Americans voted for Obama, African-Americans (due to sheer numbers) did not make up the majority of Obama's popular vote.



If your hypothesis that Obama won because he is black is correct, then that means that many white americans (plus a number of latinos, etc.) voted for Obama because he is black.
Now, do you really believe that?  I don't think so.
Obama won because his message was one of restoration, hope, and change.
Whether or not you support him, his message is the reason he won.



</answer>



<answer from>

Member since: 12 July 2008
Total points: 3228 (Level 4)

<answer>

That's kind of a bummer.



I wish him well, but I don't think he's the best person for the job.  I think he's in over his head, and some of his advisors are a bit sketchy, at best.



FWIW, I didn't think McCain was the BEST person for the job, either.



I found this article honest.  Pay attention to the part about TAXES RISING:



President Obama began this process last night, in his victory speech, when he noted that restoring the country's health might take more than a term. In the next few weeks, he should go well beyond this:



The deficit will be more than $1 trillion a year for several years
The country needs a massive new fiscal stimulus
The housing market will continue to decline through at least 2010
Interest rates and taxes will eventually have to rise (after the economy stabilizes)
Weak corporations have to be allowed to fail
Millions of homeowners will lose their house



Unemployment will probably rise to 10%
The government simply cannot "bail the country out" -- not because it lacks the will, but because it lacks the power
In short, Obama needs to acknowedge reality, erring on the side of overstating the problems and challenges, and he needs to prepare the country for several tough years. Because if he doesn't, within six months of his taking office, the country will have forgotten all about the prior administration and will instead be blaming everything on him.

http://finance.yahoo.com/tech-ticker/art...



</answer>

<answer>



If having non-diseased and tortured animals (which affects the quality and safety of the meat) means paying more, then yes.  Plus it's the large agribusnesses that torture animals and leave them in their filth--small famers farmers have fewer livestock to handle and traditional farm life is more humane and sanitary than large factory farming.  I would much rather have American produced food than have Chinese and Mexican imports that end up killing people or making them very sick.  I wish tariffs and other trade resctrictions could be in place to protect domestic businesses.  Once tariffs are in place, American companies can compete and will gain a lot more business--and can then lower prices.



Tychicus: Something tells me that you're not really a farmer--sorry.



But when you place animals cramped together in their own waste the become diseased.  They'll also have a higher fat content and little meat (but they simply inject water and often salt into the "meat" to add extra weight to it.  Do you really want less for your money?  When you put them in slow, painful, stressful, and torturous situations, they produce extra adrenaline--which is bad for us because this hormone remains in the flesh of the animals that are killed.  Sorry but there's no excuse for factory farming being like thrid world countires.  Traditional farmers have been driven out of business by factory farms and people were better off with traditional farms--like in the good old days when we had more of them and food wasn't expensive.  Monopolies and price gouging (and artificial scarcity) by agribusinesses is what leads to high prices--they should all be broken up and more Americans should be given an opportunity to farm again.  But of course, healthy organic food is not what's heavily subsidized.



Source(s):



My grandparents' farm life.  Unlike people here who know nothing about traditional farming.



</answer>

<original file>4507.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk117766.txt</current file name>




<category>



Politics & Government



Other - Politics & Government



</category>



<question from>



Jay Kay
Member since: 12 September 2006
Total points: 101 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What can we do to stop arms dealing to countries that use weapons against their own people?



Countries often use supplied weapons against their own people and, in some cases, against the very countries who supplied them with the arms in the first place. How can this be prevented?



Yahoo! Staff Note:  This is the real Jay Kay.  For further details, check out the blog at: http://uk.blog.360.yahoo.com/blog-qT1KKP...



</question>



<answer from>



ekonomix
Member since: 29 June 2006
Total points: 5114 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



How much worse is it to use weapons against your own people as opposed to your neighbours, or people a bit further away?



I actually think that if a country uses arms against the country that supplied the arms in the first place thereis some degree of poetic justice to it, on the contrary.



Do you expect an unwritten code of conduct that weapons will not be used against the supplying country but should only be used against other countries? Isn't that, even if it could ever be implemented and adhered to, extremely cynical? That would make selling arms a way to defend yourself: 'go shoot other people, kill them all if you want, but don't touch me...'



I think that we should first look at weapons that have been outlawed or should be outlawed. Think of Israel dropping cluster bombs in th elast 2 days of their invasion of Lebanon, think of Israel (I'm not picking on them,  it's just more recent) allegedly using DIME weapons that destroy animals and people but leave infrastructure intact, think of the damage land mines cause years after the conflicts have ended...



I think that the way to outlaw these would be to hit countries where it matters, in the pocket. If you sell landmines to country X and country X uses them, you will have to pay for the clean up. The directors of the corporations doing the sales and the heads of state and military of the country using the weapons should be personally responsible, declaring the corporation bankrupt would not be an option. If you supply cluster bombs, then you will have to pay for the clean up as well as the loss of income and cost of relocation of the residents of the affected areas.



Basically I am saying that the true costs of conflicts must be borne by the perpetrators and their suppliers.



This could be enforced via trade boycotts, just as those used against Iraq prior to the war, ensuring that they couldn't produce any WMD.



FInally this should be applicable to every country and corporation.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



I agree with most of your points here especially around using weapons generally.  Many answerers point out that arms dealing is a fact of life, one option is to try to regulate this more, and the only way to do this is globally through the UN. Sign the petition: http://www.controlarms.org



</asker's comment>



<comments>



scott w



Surely the best way would be for governments/armies to have control of arms manufacture, and only to be allowed to produce for their own use, thus leaving no surplus and having no profit available. It does seem silly for someone to be able to set up in this kind of business purely for profit



amira_dz



i have a question for you - do you realy care?
don't get me wrong,i love your music,and respect you,but you've done lots of things that say you don't.
peace,
jameera



</comments>



<answer from>



bapsmack...
Member since: 01 September 2006
Total points: 265 (Level 2)



</answer from>

chewychi...

<answer>



Nothing can be done.



Arms are designed to kill or incapacitate, and when someone is coming at you with a gun or a petrol bomb or a knife or even a rock, you need to knock them down before they do you in. Every State needs arms, otherwise the criminals would walk over you. If you do not supply arms, then States will build their own - witness South Africa, who, in the apartheid days, were forced to produce their own weaponry. They started with rifles, but soon acquired such expertise and produced weaponry of such quality that I would advocate purchasing some of their surplus Casspir Armoured Personnel Carriers for use with the British forces in Afghanistan.



I'm ex-Service (OK, I was a Cook), but I now provide security for HM Criminal Courts, and you should see the weaponry that ordinary British civvies carry with them. Getting rid of arms is simlpy naive.

Royal Navy CPO(CK)

<answer>



Let's all be aware that there are many countries around the globe that manufacture arms. The array of weapons is mind boggling . Those countries that manufacture arms are not really concerned about where they are shipped to . Like in the movies .The bottom line is that the arms dealer does not give a hoot about where a shipment is going as long as the payment is assured.



Today the US supplies arms to country X because of some bilateral co-operation. 3 years later things do not turn out right and so country X attacks US interests.  If there is an armed insurgency within that country the govt. in power is going to use these arms against the insurgents....who are their own people. This is plain and simple politics . Surely we do not needexamples . The international community of the very rich nations ( is it G7 ? ) is trying to prevent North Korea and Iran from going nuclear yet some countries in G7 are reported to have stockpiles of nuclear weapons. The weapons have probably been supplied by the US. Do you think that one day tehe israelis will shoot at/ bomb  US interests ?  Maybe ?



So, if you can see where I am going with this you should understand that the kind of prevention you are talking about is not possible. A few countries want to police and rule the world. The world is not fair and every dog has its day!  The answer is to destroy all arms. Is this possible ?Knowing how sick the human race has become it may not even be practical. The answer is blowing in the wind.

<answer from>



Patrick T
Member since: 27 October 2006
Total points: 106 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



The approach countries take to the sale of arms around the world varies greatly.  It is not true that all western democracies have similarly firm attitudes blocking the sale of arms to questionnable dictatorships or indeed countries in severe political turmoil.  Lobbying the government, through a dialogue with your MP is a good way to ensure the UK's policy is morally defensible and the government as a whole applies pressure to other countries to avoid arms sales to unpleasant regimes.  Concern has been raised about the UK's own policy. Crucially, countries should be encouraged to co-operate and share information in an attempt to reduce the illegal trade.



However, realistically not all countries will follow an ethical policy and countries like China and some former Soviet States have indicated they will go their own way and supply arms on their own terms.  The illegal trade is even harder to stamp out and as long as people are willing to pay for weapons people will supply them - rather like drugs.



Conflict is, unfortuantely, a fact of human existance and it is hard to see this ever changing.  As long as people feel the need to defend their territory, culture and beliefs they will use weapons to do so.  The sad reality is that people will use anything that comes to hand as a weapon to pursue their aims if they feel strongly enough.  The genocide in Rwanda and the deaths of some 800,000 people in a little other 3 months was conducted with knives, machetes and other farm implements.  Very few guns were used.



Having served in the military and witnessed aggression in Africa, the Balkans and the Midddle East I have come to the conclusion that conflict is a reality of life.  Limiting the supply of weapons to places where they will be used against innocent people is a small but important step.  However I do not believe it will ever have a dramatic difference.  Will Russia really change its policy in the North Caucasus if countries refuse to sell them weapons or will they build them themselves?



Beyond that, the bigger question we need to ask ourselves is what do we do when we see innocent people being threatened and murdered and how should we re-act to the events that are taking place every day in countries around the world.  Do we have the right and the resources to judge every tribe, people and nation and prevent them using violence against others or amongst themselves?



</answer>



<answer from>



Nutty McNutty
Member since: 23 October 2006
Total points: 151 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>

In these case both countries ended up making weapons for export themselves. You could stop countries like England holding Arms fairs too!



</answer>

<question>



What is the Home Office?



</question>



<answer from>



sassydud...
Member since: 17 September 2008
Total points: 3172 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



A Home office is a room somebody uses to run a business from their home. It is usually just used just for that.



</answer>



<answer from>



Makaveli...
Member since: 12 August 2006
Total points: 1824 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



In the UK, the Home Office is a government department that deals with immigration and internal affairs such as terrorism and home security.



</answer>



<answer from>



Bardic
Member since: 21 November 2006
Total points: 44359 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



The Home Office is the lead government department for immigration and passports, drugs policy, counter-terrorism and police.



</answer>



<answer from>



MICHAEL D
Member since: 27 November 2006
Total points: 6033 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



The UK Home Office deals in Criminal justice, Prisons, Police, Fire service, Emergency planning, Immigration, Passports, Counter terrorism and a lot more.



</answer>

or



Mum can you pick me up? I know I have a car but I'm not allowed to drive ......

In a recent news story teenager ...... .... was heavily fined for driving at the common speed limit whilst rushing his dying friend..............police at the scene said the loss of the friends life was incidental and he was not to drive over 80k's!

</answer>



<answer from>



ideaques...
Member since: 17 April 2006
Total points: 18798 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



News:
Fatalities involving young drivers have jumped in NSW. One solution might be for teens to agree to a written contract with parents setting out rules for safe driving.



["Dear mom & dad, I promise not to die while I drive."]



News:
So far, this year there have been 49 P-plate driver fatalities, nearly double the 25 killed last year – kids aged 17 and 18 on provisional licences whose lives have been cut short, leaving grieving and shocked families, friends and communities.



[Maybe it's time to sack all the driving instructors!]



New:
What's behind the sudden jump? No one seems to know. It isn't echoed in other states, and it bucks the long term trend – which is no increase or decrease over the last five years. So it seems to be a statistical anomaly.



[Why not sack the statisticians why you are at it?]



News:
What is certain is that teenager road accidents are common. Road accidents were the leading cause of death among young Australians. According to a 2005 report from the Monash University Accident and Research Centre, drivers aged 18-24 account for about 25-30 per cent of all road fatalities, but make up only about 14 per cent of all drivers in Australia.



[Give the teens a choice, if you drive, you will not have your mobile phone. If you drive, don't TEXT (SMS)]



News:
What can we do? After the shock and the anguish comes the soul searching – are we doing all we can to reduce the casualty lists?



[Lost of priviledges ... No more facebook, mobile phones, IM. Teens today need to learn that you cannot watch YouTube while driving and take that notebook PC off your dashboard.]



</answer>

<question>



Are Racist & Sexist Jokes Acceptable?



1) Yes Or No
2) Please give your reasons why
3) What would you consider a racist joke, What would you consider a sexist joke.
4) What do you think of jokes that are meant to be degrading, are they still acceptable.
5) Lastly in your opinion should any joke be off limits.



</question>



<additional details>



Well I am kind of hoping to get detailed answers, meaning can you answer in the point form I asked the question. I am just doing a research and want as much answers as possible.



</additional details>

<answer from>



Jeff Smoker
Member since: 16 January 2008
Total points: 24051 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



They are politically incorrect, which is a shame.  Stereotypes exist because they have basis in reality.  Poking fun at each other in a good natured manner is healthy for race relations.  It's much healthier than banning all discussion of race and race relations.  Look at Carlos Mencia, he pokes fun at every ethnicity including his own and the guy is genuinely funny.



That being said, as with anything else there is a line in the sand that shouldn't be crossed.  Common sense should be the guide here.  For example, telling a joke about blacks love for watermelon is much different then telling a joke about blacks being lynched.



</answer>



<answer from>



Agent Pablo
Member since: 28 October 2008
Total points: 142 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



depends in what environment, and in what context. For example if your saying something to especially offend someone then what your doing is wrong. But if your doing something to be tounge in cheek within a circle of friends who ARE what your "offending" depending on whatever context should be fine.



As long as there is no truly malice intentions behind the joke, i see minimal harm and more dangerous things in this world to worry about.



Source(s):



me



</answer>



<answer from>



Me!!!
Member since: 02 October 2008

<answer>



1) Yes
2) I think that comedy should have no rules. I honestly believe that if you don't like a comedy show or stand up comedy or comedy on the radio etc don't watch it. The problem is that when someone ays a sexist or racist joke then it will make a lot of people laugh, but will offend a few, so surely they are acceptable when the majority of people like then?
3) I'm not going to list a racist joke in case i get banned from yahoo lol, but it would be one that probably plays on racial stereotypes



4) As i said before, in my eyes comedy should have no laws. If a joke is deciding people just need to remember that it is a joke,, they may not like it, but if that's the case move on and forget about it.



5) No i don't think any jokes should be of limits, because as i've said  few times lol if people don't like that type of offensive comedy then they shouldn't watch it.



I hope that helps.

<question from>



Jay Kay
Member since: 12 September 2006
Total points: 101 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What can we do to stop arms dealing to countries that use weapons against their own people?



Countries often use supplied weapons against their own people and, in some cases, against the very countries who supplied them with the arms in the first place. How can this be prevented?

Yahoo! Staff Note:  This is the real Jay Kay.  For further details, check out the blog at: http://uk.blog.360.yahoo.com/blog-qT1KKP...



</question>



<answer from>



ekonomix
Member since: 29 June 2006
Total points: 4852 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



How much worse is it to use weapons against your own people as opposed to your neighbours, or people a bit further away?

I actually think that if a country uses arms against the country that supplied the arms in the first place thereis some degree of poetic justice to it, on the contrary.



Do you expect an unwritten code of conduct that weapons will not be used against the supplying country but should only be used against other countries? Isn't that, even if it could ever be implemented and adhered to, extremely cynical? That would make selling arms a way to defend yourself: 'go shoot other people, kill them all if you want, but don't touch me...'

I think that we should first look at weapons that have been outlawed or should be outlawed. Think of Israel dropping cluster bombs in th elast 2 days of their invasion of Lebanon, think of Israel (I'm not picking on them,  it's just more recent) allegedly using DIME weapons that destroy animals and people but leave infrastructure intact, think of the damage land mines cause years after the conflicts have ended...

I think that the way to outlaw these would be to hit countries where it matters, in the pocket. If you sell landmines to country X and country X uses them, you will have to pay for the clean up. The directors of the corporations doing the sales and the heads of state and military of the country using the weapons should be personally responsible, declaring the corporation bankrupt would not be an option. If you supply cluster bombs, then you will have to pay for the clean up as well as the loss of income and cost of relocation of the residents of the affected areas.

Basically I am saying that the true costs of conflicts must be borne by the perpetrators and their suppliers.

This could be enforced via trade boycotts, just as those used against Iraq prior to the war, ensuring that they couldn't produce any WMD.

FInally this should be applicable to every country and corporation.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



I agree with most of your points here especially around using weapons generally.  Many answerers point out that arms dealing is a fact of life, one option is to try to regulate this more, and the only way to do this is globally through the UN. Sign the petition: http://www.controlarms.org



</asker's comment>

<answer from>



timm1776
Member since: 08 July 2006
Total points: 5566 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



I don't think there is anything we can do to effectively stop arms trade with abusive regimes.



Even attempting to do so would require broad international support and an effective international body that could regulate arms deals. Unfortunately, the major international players are the ones who dominate the arms trade, and it is unlikely that they'll give up such a lucrative market. Even if the major countries did commit to controlling arms sales, new suppliers would simply enter the market. Trade in arms is much like trade in drugs. So long as there is a demand, there will always be a supply.

A better, more realistic, and more long-term solution is  to change the abusive regimes themselves. We should work to support democracy, individual rights, and freedom throughout the world. Governments which prey on their own people should be isolated and punished, and oppressed peoples should be supported when they attempt to fight back against despotic leaders.



</answer>



<answer from>



Ingrid S
Member since: 21 September 2006
Total points: 904 (Level 2)

Dan H

Total points: 140 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I wish there was a way to stop so much evil in this world, but it seems that this is the price to pay for the freedoms we enjoy in a Capitalist society.  Freedom of speech, and freedom to live as we want, also goes hand in hand with Freedom to Trade (Free Trade Economy).  From Britain's perspective, we have lost so many industries, that we have very little left to export.  Unfortunately, we do seem to have retained our expertise in producing and selling arms.  How can the Government ever be persuaded to restrict this industry which raises billions for the UK / Government!

I'm sure it's the same story for all the other countries who trade arms.

No regard seems to be given as to who the "Buyer" is... Democracy or Dictator, as long as they sign on the dotted line.....

The only way I think would be if there was a significant worldwide agreement to limit weapons production; in a similar way to the Kyoto Agreement for the environment.  However, unless ALL countries agree, AND then stick to it, it won't work.  i.e. what about the U.S (& Australia) for example who have not signed up to the Kyoto Agreement! And we all know how the U.S. as a country seems to have no regard as to carbon emissions etc.



I still prey for worldwide committment and unity in dealing with all these issues, including arms.  It just seems so hard for us "ordinary folk" to make any kind of impact when it's all linked to - and controlled by - Big Business, Power Politics, & Back handers (probably!).



Jay Kay - thank God there are people like you, who are lucky enough through talent to be in the public eye, but also have a concern for the world, and therefore potentially have more of a voice, to maybe make that little bit of difference.

For example, even this is raising these issues, and getting people to think & talk about them.  You never know....One Day...... the world will work together for the good of all...  Dan



</answer>

<answer>



Nothing can be done.

Arms are designed to kill or incapacitate, and when someone is coming at you with a gun or a petrol bomb or a knife or even a rock, you need to knock them down before they do you in. Every State needs arms, otherwise the criminals would walk over you. If you do not supply arms, then States will build their own - witness South Africa, who, in the apartheid days, were forced to produce their own weaponry. They started with rifles, but soon acquired such expertise and produced weaponry of such quality that I would advocate purchasing some of their surplus Casspir Armoured Personnel Carriers for use with the British forces in Afghanistan.

I'm ex-Service (OK, I was a Cook), but I now provide security for HM Criminal Courts, and you should see the weaponry that ordinary British civvies carry with them. Getting rid of arms is simlpy naive.

Royal Navy CPO(CK)

<answer>



The arms trade has disastrous impacts the world over, and has even managed to show its ugly head in Oxford in the guise of the Said Business school. Oxford Universities new Business school opened in 2001 was mostly funded by Wafiq Said, a Syrian with links to arms dealing who fronted £20 million of the £45 million needed to build the school. 
Most of the Said fortune is said to come from arms deals most notoriously the ‘Al Yamamah’ deal in 1986; worth around $31 billion over 10 years it is said to be one of the biggest arms deals of all time. Wafiq Said helped broker the deal between Britain and Saudi Arabia, admitting that ‘I benefited because the program led to construction in Saudi Arabia that involved my companies’. He gained directly from the deal as well because companies like BAe paid him for ‘helping this company fulfil its obligations in the middle east and Saudi Arabia in particular’. It included fighter planes and electro-shock battens used to torture political dissidents. The UK government turned a blind eye to the fact that they were directly benefiting a country which is renound for its human rights abuses especially in the area of criminal justice:

SO THE ANSWER IS - There is no no cure as all governments are corrupt. Where theres money to be made in arms dealing you will never find an honest politician world wide.



</answer>



<answer from>



Sky
Member since: 05 August 2006
Total points: 1496 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



My first thoughts were that I think this could be prevented by monitoring the companies/factories that sell/trade them. If you think about it logically, globally there must only be a few manufacturers of such weapons.



Then I slowly began to deconstruct my own answer and supposed that there is actually no right answer. The reason being that even if the manufacturers were monitored, there could easily be a corrupt system of reporting, thus circumventing the purpose of control of such weapons.



It is sad to say but the Governments that allow for the supply and retail of such weapons make a hell of a lot of money and this is the catalyst and instigator of corruption.

May be another relative answer is actually setting up a body, that could be a watchdog. All countries that have these weapons factories could be involved and take part. This could perhaps be a good idea as firstly this would make it difficult and stifle any corruption. Secondly this would be away of ensuring that no one country is a dominant superpower if the countries are all watching each other.



In the interim I would suggest that might be away forward if the countries made a collaborative effort say like the U.N. or may be some kind of convention say like the Geneva Convention but obviously for the monitoring and control of weapons. The monitoring side of things could be a short tern solution. The long term goal perhaps of this anti-weapons trading body is to I think close down and stop the manufacture of weapons altogether. How utopian of me eh?!

Jay Kay, I'm not sure how to answer this as there is no simple solution as every answer can be criticised in that even if a body was setup, there would be the involvement of bureaucracy, also the financial side of things and furthermore who and how would these countries that don't co-operate and break the rules be punished?

Countries that use weapons against there own people often operate this way as there is perhaps little democracy and a lot of corruption. The question perhaps one should have asked is how these people, these mafia type governments exist and get into power in the first place?



I hate to do it… I hate to answer a question with a question but like I said there is no right answer and to find a solution is difficult and I also think anyone that suggests merely that we just stop it is being naive and simplistic as the truth of the matter is each country likes to retain and retail and that’s the way the cookie crumbles (I'm afraid to say and end on a lighter note).



</answer>

<question from>



Captain Starkiller
Member since: 10 April 2007
Total points: 21502 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Politics



</question from>



<question>



Is this one way to help Afghanistan and fight drugs



http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2008/aug...
We in the west keep fighting the war against drugs, which ruin lives.  The lives of those taking the drugs, the lives of those who care for them, and the lives of those who addicts steal from.
The article above refers to a bloke who has travelled to Afghanistan and is helping farmers to grow other crops instead of opium (used to make heroin).  Is this the way to fight drugs, by helping people not grow them?



</question>



<additional details>



Thanks for all the answers.



</additional details>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



First it's a great story and thanks for the link.

One mans mission and I wish him well. Will it make a difference? No!

Heroin dealers are not going to go out of business if heroin ceases to exist, they will simply diversify into synthetic drugs which is far worse.

In an ideal world the pomegranate crop will never have a bad year, but I will lay odds the farmers in question have cultivated a piece of mountain for poppies as a back up crop.

Then are we intending to subsidise Israeli farmers in the pomegranate market and has the man from Delmonte said, "yes"?

The war against drugs has as much to do with the end user as the supply chain. Nobody is suggesting cutting down Kielder Forest in the hope of stopping magic mushrooms.

This is a way of helping the people growing the drugs today, but it doesn't address the drug problem.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



No. 
The obvious way to help Afghan farmers and keep them away from the Taliban is to let them grow poppies and buy the opium.
There is a very large legitimate market for opium to produce legal drugs like morphine. I have even heard there is a world shortage! 
Ideally the drug should be processed in the country to add value and create employment. 
Legitimate trade might solve the Afghan/Taliban problem, it's unlikely to be solved militarily.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



It's a good idea but the problem is the commercial crops don't pay enough. It's the same problem they're having in South America right now, why would a peasent farmer grow 100 acres of corn when ten acres of coca pays ten times as much.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



Not really, because as soon as everyone left the Taliban force them back into opium production as drug trafficking is their best source of income.

http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/...

http://www.ornstein.org/index.php/taliba...

http://www.nytimes.com/2006/09/03/world/...



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



I don't think pomegranates will ever be as profitable as poppies, somehow....

Philip H, if you think the Taliban force farmers to grow opium, you are naive in the extreme.



Opium production pre-dates the Taliban by several centuries, at the least.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>

well its one way to fight drugs.  but it wont work, nor should it.  In a free trade society we grow and trade what ever will be the most profitable.  Pomegranate just will never be as profitable as opium.



</answer>

<question from>



James A
Member since: 28 May 2006
Total points: 82 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Can anyone help re.electoral role?



is there a website or phone number that will tell were ive been living for past 20+ year, ive lived at 6 different house, just cant remember were i paid council tax?



</question>



<answer from>



Cool hal
Member since: 01 June 2006
Total points: 902 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



www.192.com wll tell you for the last 8 years.  Other than that you will have to phone each individual council.



</answer>



<answer from>



old.holl...
Member since: 12 September 2008
Total points: 370 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



There is currently no authoritative answer available anywhere.

A full electoral roll is not available anywhere on a website.  For the last few years, even those who bother to complete the electoral return to be included on the Roll have had the opportunity to opt to appear in a reduced register only (which is only made available for election purposes).

Paper copies will be available at a local library for the area in question, but these are in street order.  You are able to photocopy the individual page for a fee, but will need to know which library and which council.

Council tax records are different again. These are never disclosed (lawfully) to the public.  If you can prove who you are to the Council Tax authority, they will, however, let you have a copy of your own record of payment, which will show your address for the relevant time.



</answer>

thewrite...

Total points: 411 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Let's see, employment is a product of a successful business, so basically if the government made it easier for a business to be successful (i.e. get out of the way, lower taxes, deregulation, etc) there would be more employment... oh and more taxes collected.

When a business is burdened with high taxes after they're already experiencing losses, they produce even less, and employment will continue to drop because the business will be less successful.



</answer>

<question>



HMRC and my address change?



The quickest way to inform HMRC about my new accommodation address ? Btw I have no bills etc to confirm it yet.



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



If you have already been in contact with HMRC, you will have a tax reference number or VAT reference number.  E-mail the office, quoting the number and giving them your new details.



</answer>

It started way before Bush was elected so I'm sorry this is one thing you can't blame on him.

<answer from>



cantcu
Member since: 14 May 2006
Total points: 39761 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



It is the Republican form of Socialism!

Thomas H. Stanton, a Washington lawyer formerly at Fannie Mae and now in private practice, is the author of a new book on the enterprises, "A State of Risk."! He noted that the development of the enterprises had "privatized the profits and largely socialized the risks."



</answer>



<answer from>



Rich
Member since: 19 August 2008
Total points: 779 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Only about 5% of the money in this country is printed.  The rest is created by lending institutions; it is just digits in ledgers.  The amount of money that is available is dependent on the interest rates.  That is why the Federal Reserve controls the prime interest rate.

When lending institutions go under, it reduces the amount of money that can be lent and therefore causes interest rates to rise.  This is unacceptable because it takes control of interest rates away from government control.

When the government loses control of interest rates, it loses control of the economy.

I know this explanation may be a bit hard to follow, but I had to compress a lot into a short space.



</answer>

EDIT:  Ray - re: "freebies"

I'm a fairly low income earner as is my husband, we don't currently have medical insurance from our jobs (although I soon will have as my contract is changing and comes with free BUPA cover)  and couldn't afford the £100 a month it would cost to privately insure us in the UK (with a crappy policy).



Yet thanks to the NHS, when I am feeling ill or my child is unwell I go to the doctors and get treated without paying a penny.  As I live in Wales I don't even pay for my prescriptions.  I could have £800 of drugs, if I needed it, for nothing.

My elderly mother was diagnosed with uterine cancer in March - she too is on a low income and doesn't have "health insurance" yet she was operated on immediately and the cancer is now clear.

Now could the same thing be said of a low income family without health insurance in your country?

Yes the freebies are working out pretty well thanks.  I know when I'm sick I will get taken care of.  Unlike a lot of Americans as Michael Moore has told us.

And FWIW I think Michael Moore is a Real American Patriot.  He loves his country and his people and wants to fight for them to get a better deal.  You should be looking up to him not slagging him off.

Even when I get private health insurance with my job (in the next month or so ) I will carry on using the NHS.

<question>



Are Internet Petitions Valid?



I am having a debate with my father on whether internet petitions are valid or not.  What i think, is that most of them are a bunch of bull, but i think it is possible to have an internet petition that is valid.  I would assume that they verify signatures via IP addresses, but i am having a tough time finding the info on the matter.  So if any body knows exactly how these work, or better yet if you can direct me to a site that can tell me all of the details ( preferably a government site ) that would be great. thank you

<question>



Is the US really a free country? Are the policies of the US govt consistent with 'freedom/rights' ?



Im from the US, and I can safely say that this is NOT a free country.



A few clarifications for the post below:

"Although I have used the US govt many times below, the question I have addressed is for the entire US.

I guess I also wanted to point out the inconsistencies in the policies of the US govt, giving 'rights' for things that are not right/dangerous, and vice versa."



The Post:

Americans themselves are nice generally, but its mostly the govt that pisses me off. Kids can have guns at a very young age, and for what? Self protection? Go to some of the southern states, and see how easy it is to get a gun. Go to some of the slums in NJ (in fact, NJ is now almost full of slums) and see how many kids have guns. These kids can be serious threats to societies, only because they want to 'protect' themselves from unforeseen situations. I live in NJ, and I can safely say that the slums of Newark are spreading all over the state. No place is safe anymore.

And the brotherly city Philly has one of the biggest crime rates between the blacks and whites. Talk about brotherly. I still feel black people are not trusted by the whites, even though the whites try to be nice to them, i guess. Blacks are still discriminated in this country.

Not to forget about the rights of women. Women are treated as sex objects mostly, thanks to the misconception that Hollywood has promoted (that if you look sexy and show your bod off, you'll be a 'powerful' person). Don't forget the 'limited' role of women in the running of this country. Hence, this is the freedom for women we all talk about!

The campaign against drugs is an even bigger farce than the women rights one. The govt bans pot, which has a lot of medical benefits for the treatment of people. Alcohol is far more addicting and harmful (and kills your brain cells) than pot, yet it is pot and not alcohol that is banned. Even nicotene is more harmful and addicting as compared to pot. While in Canada, you can drink alcohol when you're 18 and even before that in European countries. People here can only drink it in public when they're 21. Pot is not banned in most European countries and not in Canada either, but it is in the US. Although I dont take drugs personally, is this a free country?

We talk about the freedom of expression in this country, yet when (looking at the minorities) the Iranian president came to Columbia University a year back, he was not even given a chance to speak at the beginning. And who was stopping him? The president of the university himself. The president of the university had already concluded his opinion of the Iranian president before letting him defend himself. And this is the president of one of the best univerisities in the US!!! I believe he should have let the Iranian president make his case , and then should have bashed him for his ideology. I feel minorities are not given proper rights in this country.



I would appreciate sensible responses from Americans and other people.



</question>



<additional details>



And oh yes, how can we forget: "The 'Patriot' Act!"



</additional details>



<answer from>



gbates31
Member since: 25 August 2008
Total points: 215 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



No this is not a free country.



The government owns all the land, a citizen is forbidden from owning land.  The government controls all the currency, citizens are forbidden from using their own.  The government controls all business, a citizen cannot run a business without government permission and must abide by all regulations.  The government controls all travel, a citizen cannot travel without government permission.  The government controls all farming and agriculture, a citizen cannot decide what he wants to grow and how much of it.  The government decides who can own what firearms and when they can be carried, a citizen must seek government permission to own and carry a firearm.  Does everyone get the idea?

There is not one single aspect of any US citizen's life that state or federal regulation does not touch.  This is not a free country.  Those that believe this is a free country only believe it because the phrase is repeated so often.



</answer>

Ed

Total points: 12969 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Monetarism is more about controlling inflation via interest rates, as opposed to the Keynesian method of controlling it via taxation. The premise of both is the same - inflation is caused by an excess of money in an economy, and the way to control it is to take some money off people. If I have to lose money, I would rather lose it as taxation (at least it gets spent on us via public spending, interest payments merely go to bank shareholders.)



</answer>

<answer>



While it may be said that Asians immigrate to Britain and may even send money etc home, it can't be said they've colonized Britain. Colonization was the subjection of a country to foreign rule; essentially an occupation by a superior (usually European) military power - we're not ruled by any Asian country, so it can simply be called immigration.



</answer>



<answer from>



Aidan
Member since: 16 May 2007
Total points: 1375 (Level 3)

<answer>



The meaning of the world colonise doesnt just cover migration it requires a certain level of migration and usually exterior force and internal vunerability.  This involves the coloniser taking all the resources and becoming culturally and economically powerful and even dominant(cultural dominance invetibally involves it getting privileged legal status eg revival  + legal stat of hebrew in Isreal/palestine). This is how it is right to say that the Americans Jews and Europeans colonised different parts of the world. Although I wouldnt go as far to say that colonisation is a euphamism for ethnic cleansing the competition between the colonisers and the usual dominance of them means that it almost always involves killing of the former inhabitants of forcing them to migrate. The Asians have moved to Britain, they have even established a cultural foothold but they certainly arent dominant. In fact it is part of Europeans historic legacy that they migrated to the west in the first place since capital, wealth, jobs and oppurtunity have been concentrated in this area of the world by the worlds colonial past.



</answer>

<question>



Isn't Palin's support for the aerial hunting of wolves the embodiment of what is wrong with conservatives?



This may or may not be true, but there is video footage and numerous articles claiming that governor Palin, the potential Vice President of the United States, supports the cruel and cowardly practice of aerial hunting of wolves:



Video:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6T85cOGc8...



Article:
http://www.slate.com/id/2199140/



This brings me to my point about Republicans. People who are on the conservative end of the political spectrum frequently extol the traditional American mores of patriotism, bravery, manliness, rugged individualism, and family values. Conversely, the portray liberals of being bereft of such lofty virtues. Yet, neoconservatives like Palin, advocate aerial hunting of wolves instead of hunting them face to face (not very manly) Right wingers, such as George W. Bush, frequently send other people's children, and not their own, to die for wars that they declare (not very brave or patriotic). They willingly take money from government subsidies when it engenders the growth of their business (not very ruggedly individualistic). These Christian conservatives talk about family values, and then nominate a woman into office who would rather spend her time promoting her political career then taking care of the special needs kid that she delivered into this world (not really an example of family values). This is hypocrisy of the highest order, don’t you think?



</question>



<answer from>



Sky Salad Clipper
Member since: 13 December 2006
Total points: 1045 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



With wolves being one of my most respected species, I can find no more reprehensible use of taxpayer money than funding the cowardly aerial killing of wolves.  The irony is that the extolled virtues you site, as bravery and family values, are often exemplified in wolves to a greater extent than in many humans.  The hypocrisy you reference is absent from wolves too.



For those who may not be familiar with the culture of wolves, there is a fantastic book: “The Last Wild Wolves, Ghosts of the Rain Forest” by Ian McAllister.  It is an eloquent expression of the value of their preservation.  It is a book that expands one’s awareness of life.

So, the simple answer to your question is yes, Palin’s support for the aerial hunting of wolves is the embodiment of what is wrong with conservatives as represented by Palin.  It represents a selfish, egocentric, hypocritical leadership that ultimately destroys the values that it gives lip service to.  It appears to me that the values represented are only adhered to when it is convenient for their selfish desires.



</answer>

<question>

Fifty-seven years is not normally classed as a long time so it is quite ________ that it took 57 years for the 6 countries of the European Coal and Steel Community to turn in the highly successful, 27 country strong, European Union that we know today.
This union has made it possible for us, the Irish nation, to prosper both economically and financially. It has provided us with the largest single market, in the world, making it easier and more cost efficient for us to import and export various goods.
On a local Irish level, this means that Irish farmers have a larger market on which to sell their produce, meaning that they need no longer worry if there is a large enough market for goods such as beef and dairy products.
On a personal level, the EU makes travelling within the union easier because not only do we have freedom of movement
between member states but we also have the added luxury of not needing to change our money within the union, unless we are travelling to either the UK or Denmark.



</question>

<answer>



I am a 71 year old grandmother and went to school in the 40'& 50's when punishments in schools was allowed. I was caned a few times for either talking or not paying attention. Yes it hurt at the time, but never made any lasting effect on me. None of the teachers were classed as sadists because they did punish us. I know that I deserved it. When I told my Mum after school she just told me that I must have deserved it or the teacher wouldn't have hit me. I had some very good teachers and I loved school, I hated to leave it when I had to. So long as the teacher knows where to draw the line and not be brutal, then I can't see any harm in it. One of our teachers couldn't hit us so she sent us along to the headmaster to doll out the punishment. And standing outside his office, which was in the school hall where everyone passing through could see me standing there, was a punishment by its self, as they knew why I was standing there, luckily this didn't happen very often. Some form of punishment should be allowed back into schools, I am sure it would help the teachers.

<answer from>



Bt
Member since: 12 February 2007
Total points: 169 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



It is no wonder that the bailout is hugely impopular, because in essence, it amounts to taking taxpayers' money to save the profit of large banks, in a "reverse Robin Hood" operation: take it from the poor and give it to the rich so they can continue to turn a profit, on the excuse that "their profit is everybody's gain".



However, if we analyze it from a strictly pragmatic point of view, it is probably true that the consequences of a massive economic breakdown will be much worse for everybody than burning taxpayers' money in this operation, unfair as it may be.



So, in my opinion, from the moral point of view it is wrong, but from the pragmatic point of view, it is necessary.



The finer points in the bailout try to mitigate this unfairness by, for instance, establishing that the banks should return the benefits of to society in general along few years, and the US government would keep tabs on that and enforce that policy. To what extent this will work, it is uncertain, especially because it is difficult to define exactly what "giving back" means in legal terms.



I am not an American, but if my country were in the United States' situation, i'd definitely be supportive of a bailout operation, but would at the same time loathe the idea. It would be a necessary evil. Letting the banks break to "teach them a lesson" would end up having adverse consequences on millions of people who don't have anything to do with the crisis, so in essence we'd be making 1000 people suffer in order to punish 10, and that's harder to accept than any bailout plan.



Source(s):



Just my thoughts.



</answer>



<answer from>

Member since: 23 July 2008

<original file>3596.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk52209.txt</current file name>




<category>



Politics & Government



Other - Politics & Government



</category>



<question from>



.
Member since: 26 April 2006
Total points: 6068 (Level 5)



</question from>



<question>



The bail out bill passed. How bad are we screwed ?



The bail out bill passed. How bad are we screwed ? Is it time to dig a rabbit hole to live in ?



</question>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



It still has to pass the house.  You must have had a liberal for a political science teacher.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



The bill passes the House tomorrow ?  Then we're screwed.
The bill doesn't pass the House tomorrow.  We're screwed even more.



A good analogy:
You live in a city with various neighbors.  One neighbor vigorously chain-smokes, even in bed.
The neighbor next door to him hoards gasoline in his garage...he's afraid of rising gasoline prices.
The chain-smoker eventually lights his bed and house on fire.  The fire spreads to the neighbor with stored gasoline.  The gasoline explodes into your whole neighborhood.  Houses are now burning all around your home.
Think of the Govt's bailout as trying to quench the fire before it spreads to your home.



Yes, you'll still pay for it.
Yes, the idiot chain-smoker has died and left you a mess.
But, how much could you end up paying if the fire isn't quenched?



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



It passed in the Senate. Learn how the government works. The House is voting tomorrow.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



It only passed in the Senate yesterday, and just barely at that.



The vote in the House of Congress is tomorrow. Remember that is was the Republicans in the House that had the strongest reservations against the first version of the bill



The last step is for Bush to sign it. He's pretty desperate though and is likely to sign even with the assorted goodies they added on to make the deal sweeter for the Republican House.



And remember, the cash for this is gonna be part of our deficit, we will borrow it from China initially. The firms that receive the cash are obligated to pay it back under this bill, and the govt will hold the mortgages till they are worth some cash as well. This is a crunch, but not a bankruptcy. Only time will really tell



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



“I am from the government, and I am here to help.”  This is one of the scariest phrases in the English language.  There are some serious problems in our great country; with the economy being the one on everyone’s mind these days, and more government cannot be our only option.  Our leaders in Washington are faced with difficult decisions everyday and I applaud their efforts to fix all of my problems, but $700 Billion more debt is not going to help me or my children.



The average American either does not own stocks or has no idea what they have invested in through their 401K plan.  However, we all struggle to keep current on our mortgage, utilities, car, and credit card payments.  If the government wants to “bailout” someone, I am here ready, willing, and able to put the money to good use – but it is MY money that they want to give me!  They want to take my tax dollars and give it to a company so that it won’t have to face the troubles that most of America is facing – debt.  They want to cover the 7% of mortgages that are in foreclosure and the so-called “golden parachutes” for the executives that funded these bad loans in the first place.  I say, hold the executives accountable for their mistakes.  If I make bad decisions in me job, then I am fired or at the very least reprimanded for my actions.  Wall Street is the only place in the world that I know of that REWARDS incompetence.  These guys were supposed to be financial geniuses but they CHOSE to fund bad loans because they got greedy and now their companies are failing.  Why do they deserve to be bailed out at all?



The general consensus is that the world as we know it will cease to exist unless Washington bails out Corporate America.  Well, if they want to “help,” why not help those of us who are struggling here on Main Street, not Wall Street.  Take ½ of $700 Billion (that’s $350 Billion) and give it back to those who can use it.  The argument against this is that the government cannot MAKE people use money that they send out how they want them to.



Why not?  The government is very fond of vouchers.  Why not send out the money in the form of mortgage vouchers?



There are approximately 135,260,000 U.S. Taxpayers, if 75% of them own their own home, then that is approximately 101,445,000 people.  $350 Billion split between them would be about $3,550 per person.  If that money were sent out to the American people in the form of mortgage vouchers, we could “bailout” the economy for ½ of what the government wants to spend.  The surplus in the average American home that could be provided by these vouchers would fund the stock market – either directly by people investing, or indirectly by people buying more consumer goods.  The banks would receive the vouchers from the government anyway through the mortgage payments and then they would have to do what the rest of us have to do when we get ourselves into a financial mess – WORK HARD AND SACRAFICE UNTIL WE CAN GET OURSELVES OUT OF IT!!!



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



Dig all you want but WE will be fine unless Obama gets elected then we're screwed.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



IF it passes the house, we will be saved from a meltdown.  It's a good thing.



</answer>

<answer>



I am a 71 year old grandmother and went to school in the 40'& 50's when punishments in schools was allowed. I was caned a few times for either talking or not paying attention. Yes it hurt at the time, but never made any lasting effect on me. None of the teachers were classed as sadists because they did punish us. I know that I deserved it. When I told my Mum after school she just told me that I must have deserved it or the teacher wouldn't have hit me. I had some very good teachers and I loved school, I hated to leave it when I had to. So long as the teacher knows where to draw the line and not be brutal, then I can't see any harm in it. One of our teachers couldn't hit us so she sent us along to the headmaster to doll out the punishment. And standing outside his office, which was in the school hall where everyone passing through could see me standing there, was a punishment by its self, as they knew why I was standing there, luckily this didn't happen very often. Some form of punishment should be allowed back into schools, I am sure it would help the teachers.

<answer from>



Richard Dawkins
Member since: 02 September 2008
Total points: 107 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Scotland is a voluntary member of the union. The Scottish electorate have the right (they have always had the right since act of union in 1707) to leave the union at any time they choose. Scotland should be independent as soon as the majority vote for it. (but ONLY if the majority vote for it).



It really annoys me that some english people seem to think that it is up to england to decide whether we should have independence or not. I wish they would take even just a few minutes to at least try and understand how democracy works within the United Kingdom.



Historically, (in 1707) it was England who needed Scotland to join them in the union, not the other way around. England could not have risked a Scottish alliance with the French as this would have meant almost certain destruction for the English nation. The situation is different now but the United Kingdom would be weaker without Scotland as part of it. The idea that Scotland could not manage its own affairs is ridiculous. The global trend towards self-determination has shown the success of many a poorer nation than Scotland thrive following their own independence.



</answer>

<answer>



Ah, Kevin B: I put my source at the bottom of my comment, so look before you accuse me of not doing my research. 8 years in the Illinois State Senate plus 2 in the U.S. Senate equals 10.  People only like to talk about his 2 years in the U.S. Senate and ignore the State Senator position.



Regarding Obama: 10 years in the Senate is not a 'little experience".  He  also serves on 3 out of the 4 Foreign Relations Committees. "He is the Chair of the Subcommittee on European Relations and serves on the Subcommittees on African Affairs; East Asia and Pacific Affairs; and International Development and Foreign Assistance, Economic Affairs, and International Environmental Protection. This cross-section of subcommittees places him in a unique position of having knowledge about Asian, African and European issues.
He has visited Russia, Ukraine, and Azerbaijan in Asia; Iraq, Israel, Jordan, Kuwait, and the Palestinian Territories in the Middle East; and Chad, Djibouti, Ethiopia, Kenya, and South Africa in Africa. Obama has also co-sponsored the "Lugar-Obama Act" with Republican Senator Richard Lugar who was Chairman of the Committee on Foreign Relations at the time."
Do more research, cowboy...his life experience is extensive and admirable.  He's also spent more time trying to help the poor (in Chicago) than George Bush has spent reading the comics (and that's a lot of time).  The list goes on and on...do some disciplined research yourself.

<answer from>



Bryan S
Member since: 08 January 2008
Total points: 772 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



The bail out bill is like a "debt consolidation" line of credit on your house.  So, if you were to max out your credit cards, then finding it difficult to pay them off, you borrow money using a second mortgage to pay off said credit cards.  If you do not change (and the vast majority of people do not) your way of spending, then you will once again max out your cards, plus now you will also have to pay the second mortgage.



All this to say, what Wall Street needs is a credit counseling course, not a tax payer financed buy out.  They need to make a sea change in the way they operate, or we will be right back here in very short order.



</answer>
