<question>



Maverick?what is a maverick?



An unbranded range animal, especially a calf that has become separated from its mother, traditionally considered the property of the first person who brands it. OMG do you people really want a maverick in charge of America?



</question>



<answer from>



pdevans1...
Member since: 04 December 2006
Total points: 18320 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



also  means a lone dissenter, as an intellectual, an artist, or a politician, who takes an independent stand apart from his or her associates.



clue : sometimes  words  have  MORE than  one  meaning



Source(s):



http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/m...



</answer>



<answer from>



ericakim...
Member since: 31 July 2008
Total points: 589 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Maverick was the family name of a rancher in Texas who did not brand his cattle.  Be it for PETA type reasons, or something else.  So when other ranchers came across unbranded cattle they were considered a Maverick, or belonging to the Maverick Ranch.  Get your facts straight.



Source(s):



For the record there is still a maverick family out there, and they are appaled that the rich history of their family name has been politisized by McCain.  The only reason this is a word is because of the Family...It is a FAMILY NAME



</answer>

<current file name>yqa_uk58671.txt</current file name>




<category>



Politics & Government



Other - Politics & Government



</category>



<question from>



ilidanst...
Member since: 16 September 2006
Total points: 263 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



What is water democracy?



I need a clear definition of water democracy, its main idea and other concepts that are vital in understanding this concept.



Thanks.



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



National Convention on Water Democracy



National Convention on Building Water Democracy, Resisting Water Privatization, 1 st and 2 nd February 2006 at Indian Social Institute, Lodhi Road, New Delhi, Organized by Navdanya/Research Foundation for Science Technology and Ecology



A National Convention on Building Water Democracy, Resisting Water Privatization held at Indian Social Institute, Lodhi Road New Delhi organised by Navdanya Research Foundation for Science Technology and Ecology on 1 st and 2 nd February 2006.



Convention was opened by Dr. Vandana Shiva – Director, RFSTE who addressed the crisis our rivers and waters are facing. The combination of pollution, diversion through dams and privatization is killing our rivers and water bodies. One indication of this crisis is the refusal of people to bathe in the holy Ganga at Allahabad during the Maghmela because of the pollution which has increased after the damming of Bhagirathi at Tehri.



Dr. Shiva stated that if our rivers die, our civilization will die. Dr. Ramaswamy R Iyer, Former Secretary, Ministry of Water Resources, Government of India showed that the mega projects that are killing our rivers are unnecessary in a country as large as India with more than a billion people. Decentralized systems of water conservation and management are the most effective means to provide water for all. Movements engaged in rejuvenation of water resources shared their experience of success, can bring dead rivers and water bodies to lives.



Leaders of the water renewal movements like Mr. Anupam Mishra of Gandhi Peace Foundation, Mr. Rajendra Singh of Tarun Bharat Sangh addressed the Convention. Sessions in Peoples’s Alternatives for Water conservation and rejuvenation were addressed by Mr. Manu Bhatnagar of INTACH, Dr. Anil Gautam and Mr. Ayan Biswas of Peoples Science Institute, Dehradun.



Sessions in Building Water Democracy in Ganga and Yamuna were contributed by Mr. Sunderlal Bahuguna of Chipko Information Centre, Tehri, Prof. Dhrubajyoti Ghosh, Vice Chairman, South Asian IUCN, Prof. H.C. Nainwal, Reader, HNB Garhwal University, Srinagar, Uttranchal, Commander Sureshwar Sinha of Pani Morcha, Mr. Shantanam Seth of Ahimsa Trust and United Nations Volunteer Programme, Mr. Vimalendu Jha of We for Yahuma.



The Convention has also had the first screening of film “Ganga from the Ground Up”, The film “Jijivisha” on the death of the Yamuna was also screened.



Sessions on Resisting Privatisation was addressed by Prof. Banwarilal Sharma – Convenor, Azadi Bachao Andolan, Mr. S.A. Naqvi of Water Workers Alliance, Dr. Sudhirendra Sharma of the Ecological Foundation.



The National Convention condemned the attempt to privatize and commodify our precious water resources through World Bank driven water sector reforms. Different states like Rajasthan and Mahararashtra are creating new Water Policies and Water Laws declaring water a state property, which can then be converted into private property. We demand that these policies and laws be changed to recognized water as people’s common property. We will build movements of water democracy to protect water and people’s right to water.



The Convention resolved to defend water as a living resource, a gift of nature, a fundamental right of all, water is not a market commodity. It is not a Sate property. It is nature’s most vital resource, a common property, a basic need. It must stay under the control of society, which dedicates to itself to its conservation. This is Jal Swaraj, This is Water Democracy.



Source(s):



National Convention on Water Democracy
... democracy. Seed sovereignty. Food sovereignty. Water ... National Convention on Water Democracy. People's agenda for rejuvenation for Indian agriculture ...
navdanya.org/news/06feb2.htm



</answer>

<answer>



The buy-out package was never about fixing the problems of the country or our economy. It was a gift to the corporate overlords.



If Congress really wanted to fix the mess, it would have worked from the bottom up, not the top down.



If Congress had given every taxpayer $1 million:
Most people would have enough to pay off their mortgages, thereby eliminating the foreclosure problem, and pay off their other debts like car loans, student loans, etc..., providing that "liquidity" to back to the banks, which would then have opened up the credit markets.
People would have had enough to purchase some "big ticket" items like appliances and TVs, which would have increased demand in the manufacturing sector, and increased employment.
People would have stashed some away, increasing the national savings rate.
People would have bought stocks, or invested more in their retirements funds, thereby bouying the market.
And it all would have cost less than $300 million.



Make no mistake, by subsidizing irresponsibility on Wall Street, by socializing the debts and borrowing money from China to prop up our economy, we are doomed to failure.



</answer>

<question>



Does it make more sense to have the Government print their own money rather then a privately owned bank?



I mean from my understanding when the privately owned banks (Federal Reserve)  print money they also tack on interest rates and gain more power than even the Government. If the Government printed it's own money there wouldn't be interest rates. Now I understand printing money shouldn't be the answer because it causes inflation, but as long as their going to keep doing it at least make sense of it and have the Government do it.



"If the American people ever allowed the banks to control the issuance of their currency, the banks and corporations that will grow up around them will deprive the people of all property, until their children will wake up homeless on the continent their fathers once occoupied." Thomas Jefferson.



</question>



<answer from>



R.M. Wolcott
Member since: 02 October 2008
Total points: 133 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



The government does control the money from printed by the bank. Over time, the Federal Reserve has become much more private. Because of this, two people basically have control of all money in the country, the Secretary of Commerce and the President of the Federal Reserve. It's convenient that you quoted Jefferson, because although he was opposed to the bank, since it had already existed, he took advantage of it and made the largest purchase of property with its bank notes. Jefferson was opposed to a national bank and speculation. Jefferson as president used the national bank to buy a huge mass of land from the French, called the Louisiana Purchase. He then took this new acquired land and gave it to speculators. I am not discrediting Jefferson from making this decision, but I am noting that you can only take everything that a power seeker says as a grain of salt. Most people change when they actually gain power, at least to some extent.



</answer>

<question>



Wall Street now runs through Washington.?



Beginning in January, the House and Senate will hold a series of hearings to determine what caused the current financial crisis, and what reasonable regulations will be needed to prevent it from happening again, said Democratic leaders.



In addition, lawmakers will wrestle with what sort of institution replaces the now US-owned housing giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, said Mr. Frank.



"We have to rewrite housing finance in America," they claim
Instead of periodic government audits, they now face the prospect of dozens of regulators from the Federal Reserve and Office of the Comptroller of the Currency working permanently in their offices, peering into their business all the time.



So what does this all mean for the free market system? Have we seen the end of capitalism itself?



</question>

<answer>



Ok- I just asked a question- HOW DID HE DO IT?  What exactly did he do- Specifics
Because I could say the same thing about the Democrats.  (except I can give specifics)



For instance-



In 1977- 78 The Carter (D) administration thought it should be the right of anyone to own a home. He did some mild legislation to make it esier for low income people to get one. Then in the Clinton Administration it was given steroids. This was based on a mistake in a Harvard Study that 'proved' subtle discirimination was a practice in the housing market because a black man with $10 million in assets was denied a $60,000 mortgage and a white man got it. Later they realized that the Black man only had $1000 in assets, but who cares about accuracy, right?



Well, have you ever seen those little EHO things? That's what came out of all of this. Banks started giving loans without proof of income for fear of the government messing them up by pointing the finger and yelling racist at them. A lot of people got loans that had no business getting them. Well, add to that the 0% interest loan. People saw they could buy a house that was WAY out of their price range at a low monthly price. The governemtn TOLD them to make these so everyone could own a home! Unforetuneatley the interest started kicking in. This was called an ARM- Adjustable Rate Interest. Well- This raised their mortgage so far taht they just couldn't pay anymore, and the house was forclosed upon. Enough of these and all of a sudden the banks had all this debt that wasn't being paid, which cause foreclosures.



Now, I realize the republicans had their part in this fiasco, the congress from 2000-2006 was basically worthless as far as republicans go, However, it was mainly Democrats that put us there in the first place.



Now, one of the biggest lenders was a sorta government sorta private set of companies called Fannie may and Freddie Mac. Yeah. They had these CEOs that took all of these bad loans because all it showed on the books was the fact that it was a loan. Loans mean income, and income is good. This gave the CEOs VERY large bonuses, so of course they wanted all of these bad loans- it lined their pockets! People like Obama's advisor, Franklin Raines . He got about $50 million from it. Jim Johnson also got rich- He also woks with Obama.



McCain tried to reform this whole thing (it's on record) but was stopped by the Democrats.

<answer>

<answer from>



ioerr
Member since: 25 September 2006
Total points: 11735 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yahoo's programming will automatically delete questions if they're reported by enough other users.



Yahoo has an email address, where you can send an appeal and ask for the question to be restored.  In a day or two, some sort of actual human will read your appeal.  If they think your question was deleted unfairly, it will be restored.



Not that anyone would ever see it again anyway, but that's the system they use.



If Yahoo hasn't told you about their email address for appealing your deletion, it's:



answers-abuse@cc.yahoo-inc.com



</answer>

Ok- I just asked a question- HOW DID HE DO IT?  What exactly did he do- Specifics
Because I could say the same thing about the Democrats.  (except I can give specifics)



For instance-



In 1977- 78 The Carter (D) administration thought it should be the right of anyone to own a home. He did some mild legislation to make it esier for low income people to get one. Then in the Clinton Administration it was given steroids. This was based on a mistake in a Harvard Study that 'proved' subtle discirimination was a practice in the housing market because a black man with $10 million in assets was denied a $60,000 mortgage and a white man got it. Later they realized that the Black man only had $1000 in assets, but who cares about accuracy, right?



Well, have you ever seen those little EHO things? That's what came out of all of this. Banks started giving loans without proof of income for fear of the government messing them up by pointing the finger and yelling racist at them. A lot of people got loans that had no business getting them. Well, add to that the 0% interest loan. People saw they could buy a house that was WAY out of their price range at a low monthly price. The governemtn TOLD them to make these so everyone could own a home! Unforetuneatley the interest started kicking in. This was called an ARM- Adjustable Rate Interest. Well- This raised their mortgage so far taht they just couldn't pay anymore, and the house was forclosed upon. Enough of these and all of a sudden the banks had all this debt that wasn't being paid, which cause foreclosures.



Now, I realize the republicans had their part in this fiasco, the congress from 2000-2006 was basically worthless as far as republicans go, However, it was mainly Democrats that put us there in the first place.



Now, one of the biggest lenders was a sorta government sorta private set of companies called Fannie may and Freddie Mac. Yeah. They had these CEOs that took all of these bad loans because all it showed on the books was the fact that it was a loan. Loans mean income, and income is good. This gave the CEOs VERY large bonuses, so of course they wanted all of these bad loans- it lined their pockets! People like Obama's advisor, Franklin Raines . He got about $50 million from it. Jim Johnson also got rich- He also woks with Obama.



McCain tried to reform this whole thing (it's on record) but was stopped by the Democrats.

35. Do you support state legislation to:

<question>



Want to Know More About Obama's Taxing Policy?

Is it true that people who earn more than $250K from the sale of a house will have to pay more taxes? Again, the same with retirement plans? By how much, exactly?

<answer from>



Richard_...
Member since: 20 January 2008
Total points: 5465 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



The 250 k applies to income.



It doesn't apply to house sales  -  which isn't income.



It doesn't apply to retirement plans - which are always treated differently for tax purposes.

I'm just curious if some of you actually read what's written here....



"first of all, both parties are lying their eyes out right now to get elected. in the current economic climate, there will be nothing done about anything.



my plan is let the big insurance companies handle things. the government does nothing but mandate the new laws. everyone goes into a pool of which the insurance companies draft names by lottery, it's random. no one can be turned down. if you have insurance, you don't have to be a part of the plan. everyone else who has been drafted pays a premium to the carrier that drafted them. (the insurance companies make huge bucks, thus driving the cost on insurance down) and for those who can't pay, the gov picks up the tab. it's so freakin' simple!



it's just like auto liability insurance. once it was mandated, the price fell to nill.



oh, also, i would limit the cost of some procedures like cat scans, x-rays and other boon doggles that bankrupt the system."



YEAH, THANKS...



"I can tell you that the proposed $5000 a year is way too low for anyone that has serious problems. Those people would be screwed when they would have to start paying tens of thousands of dollars of their money just to get the necessary medications and surgeries."



AGAIN, THANKS



"obama = health care
mccane= no health care... 5000$ tax credit for health care, but no one will use it on healthcare!"



THANK YOU FOR ALL OF YOUR OPINIONS



</additional details>

I can assure you one of that the greedy capitalists that surround him would have sold a book deal by now if there were a shred of truth to it.



First of all, the WMD's in Iraq weren't the centerpiece of the logic behind the war, the repeated violations of the peace from the invasion of Kuwait was, and second, the fact that Hussein did have two members of his cabinet charged with development and use of WMD's suggests that the threat was more real than you imagine, and third, a buttload of yellowcake was recently found in Iraq and quietly sent to Canada to be processed for peaceful useage.



The geneva convention doesn't apply to non-uniformed combatants.



You're right about suspension of Habeus Corpus, I'll give you that.  The Constitution doesn't give the President the power to do that, it belongs to Congress.



US Attorneys work for the President.  He could fire them all if he wanted to, and doesn't need a reason. Clinton did so.



If you're upset about profits from Put Options, why aren't you excited about special favors on loans? A LOT of Congressmen got special deals from Countrywide.  There's more than one kind of corruption.



If you keep focusing on the not-necessarily-true "crimes" of Bush, you're going to keep overlooking the obvious corruption of others in your own party.



Neither is as pure as the driven snow.  Neither deserves your blind support, even if that's the only kind you seem to have available.

<answer from>



healing wings
Member since: 05 February 2007
Total points: 3697 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Probably neither will really provide healthcare where someone like me , a nurse of 40 years, taking care of every illness you can imagine, will actually have insurance to get a physical or blood work or check-up myself.  It's all just lies, but especially McCain, with 13000 pages of health reports in, whatever, 8 years, more than ten nursing homes would generate in health pages health over that time span, won't care that I don't have one paragraph of a health page for 30 years.  He is either ready to be dead or a hypochondriac to generate 13000 pages over a few years, while the rest of us trot our bodies out over ice on New years and every holiday and day of the week without a single checkup.



</answer>



<answer from>



JoelKatz
Member since: 15 May 2008
Total points: 11650 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Unfortunately, health care is too screwed up in this country for anyone to fix it any time soon. And the things that would actually improve the quality and cost of care are so politically unpopular that no mainstream politician will even mention them.



Ask yourself this question: Suppose a 92 year old retiree with $75,000 in the bank had some disease that could be cured for $1 million (say it actually costs that much to manufacture a dose of the cure). Without the cure, they will die in a week. With the cure, they will likely live for 5-10 more years. Should they get the cure? And if so, who should pay for it?



The big problem in this country is that we have decided that there must be one and only one standard of care, and everyone must either buy that standard of care or have none at all. Imagine if we decided car safety was so important that everyone had to either buy the safest Volvo there is or not have a car. Well, the average car would cost a lot more than it does now, and a lot of people couldn't afford a car. And a government plan to give everyone a car would cost a hell of a lot more than it should.



Until we have the political will to confront those kinds of issues, our health care will be totally screwed up.



</answer>

<question from>



j2k43
Member since: 13 April 2007
Total points: 187 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Ema - people who know or have ema (the goverment pay u for being in full time educations from the age of 16+)?



I have applied for ema, and am just wondering.. i know u have to have full attendance for that week to get your money but what if you miss a day because of a religious festival, do they still not give u ur money under these circumstances? that's not fair if not, right?



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



If you can produce a letter from your parents giving you permission and the school deems it an acceptable excuse, then you will get paid.



Only unauthorised absence is counted against you.



Source(s):



Used to administer EMA



</answer>

<answer>



No. There is an oversight board and judicial review, but it doesn't matter. The Bush bailout bill will fail because it does not address the roots of the current financial crisis, namely rapidly falling real estate prices sparked by the increase in the federal funds rate that ignited a wave of sub-prime mortgage foreclosures that has brought all but the highest end of the real estate market and the market for bank-owned real estate to a standstill.



That $700 billion is headed for the trash heap. Banks will sell their illiquid assets to the TARP fund and then instead of re-lending money to qualified borrowers, which is the whole purpose of the plan, they will sit on their hands and make only ultra-safe loans while purchasing government securities with the remainder, The credit crisis will persist and this will become a very deep recession and perhaps a depression since asset values will continue to fall which will further constrict lending which will cause greater unemployment which will further reduce consumer demand for products and services which will further damage the real economy that the financial economy will not lend to on reasonable terms.



The Bush bailout plan will fail. The imbecile running the Treasury Department doesn't have a Plan B, and he should have been fired in the first place when he decided to let Lehman Brothers fail because Lehman Brothers, unlike AIG, didn't owe $20 billion to his old firm Goldman Sachs.



The Bush-Cheney administration is a complete failure on both the foreign policy front and the domestic policy front and there's more of the same in store with a McCain administration. You should be a little more concerned with the bigger question of which ticket is more likely to fix the very serious problems besetting this economy and the global economy.



</answer>

<original file>323.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk78190.txt</current file name>




<category>



Politics & Government



Other - Politics & Government



</category>



<question from>



Earl
Member since: 16 September 2007
Total points: 6031 (Level 5)



</question from>



<question>



How much influence has Alan Greenspan had on the current economic situation?



GREENSPAN GOT HIS START WITH AYN RAND



In 1966, Ayn Rand collected a series of essays into the book, "Capitalism: The Unknown Ideal." Twenty of the essays in the were written by Rand. The rest came from a trio of Rand's acolytes, followers who had already been writing the newsletter of her "Objectivist" cult for more than a decade. Among these were three essays from a member of Rand's inner circle; an economic advisor and dropout from the graduate economics program at Columbia - Alan Greenspan.
Greenspan was such a close friend of Rand's, that she passed him manuscript pages of Atlas Shrugged while the book was being written. He paid rapt attention to her tale of mysterious genius John Galt - brilliant engineer, physicist, philosopher, and organizer. Galt, who shows the world who is really in charge by leading a rebellion of industrialists against laws that interfere with their companies, was in perfect agreement with the essays that Greenspan was writing at the time. In those essays, Greenspan rails against the "statists" and their desire to blame failures leading to the Great Depression on greed and unsafe lending practices. Instead, says Greenspan, the economy was experiencing a "mild contraction" which would have amounted to nothing, had the government not overreacted. Greenspan also attacks the "welfare state" and its schemes to "confiscate the wealth of the productive members of society."
When John Galt leads his own inner circle of polymath geniuses to abandon the working classes and form a objectivist paradise, Greenspan must have cheered.
The essays Greenspan contributed to the 1966 collection, like the rest of the book, praised the idea of unfettered, unrestricted, unregulated, laissez-faire capitalism. Sure, there were problems in the system as it existed at the time, but those problems were not the fault of capitalism. Real capitalism, pure capitalism, had never been tried. Under pure capitalism, there would be a complete "separation of capitalism and state," and the resulting markets would be self-governing and self-correcting. It was only the intrusion of regulations into the system that brought on instability and immorality. Kick government out, and the system would not only flourish, but express the innate reasoning and positive force of selfishness.
Chief disciple Greenspan carried this torch for the next half-century and beyond. Pro-business conservatives (not surprisingly) found great comfort in a philosophy that said squeezing every dime out of the system was not only fair, but the only moral solution. Not long after the publication of his essays in Rand's book, Greenspan was invited to become an advisor to the Nixon administration. When Ford replaced Nixon, Greenspan became the chair of the Council of Economic Advisors. And when Reagan took power, Greenspan was no longer the voice crying in the wilderness, he was the very center of the establishment. Objectivism and Conservatism had united in Market Fundamentalism, and that force was on a jihad against regulation of any kind.
For the next thirty years, Greenspan would cheer the deregulation of the S&Ls and join John McCain in trying to protect Charles Keating from regulators. He would praise the deregulation of energy trading, and assure everyone that companies like Enron were pointing the way to greater efficiency and lower consumer prices - and collect the 2000 "Enron Prize" in exchange. He would urge not only the creation of credit default swaps, but applaud their lack of regulation and invisibility in the system. He would argue against oversight, against limits on CEO pay, and for the increasingly complex systems by which banks generated new instruments of credit.
No one person did more to spread Rand's message of unregulated markets, unconstrained free trade, and unlimited power for corporate officers than Alan Greenspan.



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



None



</answer>

At the time our constitution was written how would this case be handled?



A woman is talking to another woman.  A man comes up and grabs their money.  A woman tries to keep him from doing this.  He punches her in the stomach.  She has a premature birth and the baby dies.  What charges were brought against the man?  He caused the early birth and eventual death of the fetus?  Was he charged with murder or simply the assault and battery of the woman?



Wouldn't this situation determine the view of constitutional status of a fetus?



</question>



<additional details>



See I see abortion as murder but the choice of legality at the state level or by constitutional ammendment.  But if you are looking at it based on the constitution then this is simple.  The case was murder in the first degree.  The fetus was determined to have value of life.  That should legally conclude abortion doctors and women should be viewed by those standards.

<answer>

<answer>



Legitimate government function = function that can only be solved by the collective.  Examples:  Police, fire, roads.



Not legitimate: Schools, protection from ourselves (prohibition, smoking laws, etc.).  Anything where government oversteps its limits set forth in the Constitution, which are many.  In other words, I don't think its OK for socialists like you to say socialism is nifty simply because government has already overstepped its Constitutional authority.

<answer>



I think it depends. If you were addressing him in person, I would not use his first name. Even though he is a pretty down-to-earth guy, it is not polite. If you are talking about him in a formal setting (e.g. you are giving a speech and you want to quote him), you should address him as Senator Obama or depending on the outcome of the election, President Obama. If you are referring to him at home or with friends, I don't think it matters.



</answer>

<question>



What does "patriotism" mean to you?



When you hear patriotic, or patriotism, what is the first thing that comes to your mind? What does loving one's country mean exactly? Would you stand by your country even if it was doing something wrong? Or when you say you love America, do you really just mean you like baseball and apple pie?



</question>



<additional details>



Please do not use this as an opportunity to support your presidential canidate.



</additional details>



<answer from>



average Joe
Member since: 28 November 2007
Total points: 6532 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I think this song from a film I saw in the first grade back in 1947 describes the way Americans used to  feel about their country.
It seems Patriotism has gone out of fashion in this country since the 60s ,but this is still a great country .
This song "The House I live in" by Frank Sinatra pretty well sums up my feelings about it.



What is America to me
A name, a map, or a flag I see
A certain word, democracy
What is America to me



The house I live in
A plot of earth, a street
The grocer and the butcher
Or the people that I meet



The children in the playground
The faces that I see
All races and religions
That's America to me



The place I work in
The worker by my side
The little town the city
Where my people lived and died



The howdy and the handshake



The air of feeling free
And the right to speak your mind out
That's America to me



The things I see about me
The big things and the small
That little corner newsstand
Or the house a mile tall



The wedding and the churchyard
The laughter and the tears
And the dream that's been a growing



For more than two hundred years



The town I live in
The street, the house, the room
The pavement of the city
Or the garden all in bloom



The church the school the clubhouse
The millions lights I see
But especially the people
- Yes especially the people
That's America to me.



and Yes I do like apple pie but (to exericise my right as an American to think for myself)  Baseball? ...Not so much



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thank you, that song really does explain it all.



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



arunmada...
Member since: 12 July 2006
Total points: 4183 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Patriotism is the positive feeling of ones country.It's basically love and devotion to one nation.



In our modern world,the idea of countries on the line of ethnicity,or just for the sake of being a nation is kinda outdated. That's because nowadays,many nations have intermixed cultures,many different ethnicity,and many different people.



So nowadays,nations are more about ideals such as Democracy,Freedom,Rights etc. Would I feel patriotic for a nation that supports one ethnicity,only one culture,only one idea,of course not.The largest empires fall because they fail to adapt to changing times and evolving culture. The Roman Empire couldn't adapt to Christianity, that's one example.



But the U.S., despite some bigotry has been able to support a vast amount of cultures,people,ideas and religions. That kind of tolerance is the key to success of any nation,and the ideals of a country that supports something like that should be defended to the death.



In this globalized world,things aren't too centered on nations,they are more about trade,capitalism,finance etc.Nations only represent the ideology,that's what makes them worthy of defending.



So why do I love America?Not because it's the most powerful,not because it's not the underdog,and not because it's the most wealthy,but because it supports the idea that everyone has the right to that.



</answer>



<answer from>



Blue_Bee
Member since: 01 May 2008
Total points: 1039 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Would you stand by your country even if it was doing something wrong? - Of course, but I wouldn't try to pretend or stubbornly try to deny there being a problem. That is Nationalism. Don't confuse that with Patriotism.



Patriotism - the love of one's country I think means that you love and care about her enough to see when things are going wrong and try to steer it back on track. Think of a parents love of a child. The parent who loves their kid enough to scold them and teach them right from wrong, who loves them IN SPITE OF sometimes disappointing behavior and through it all never stops hoping for the absolute best, never stops striving for success. Thats patriotism.



</answer>

<question>



Would having a mandatory obligation to do community service every week violate the Constitution?



I don't think it would, but we would have the right to strike and petition since there's the 1st Amendment. Right?



</question>



<additional details>



This is a "what if..." question.



I never said that I want to make people into slaves. This is for my English paper and I just wanted your thoughts.



</additional details>

<answer from>



KENTA (The Champ is Here)
Member since: 29 September 2007
Total points: 6479 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



It depends.  You don't HAVE to, but if it's a requirement for school, they would be in the right to give you a lesser grade in school.  Basically like everything you have the choice not to, but you have consequences for your actions.



In private schools this is especially true.  Just suck it up and do the community service.  It'll be easier for you to get into college that way.



Just assuming this is the situation.  I apologize if I'm wrong.



Edit:  Funny, there are already private schools around the country that explicitly require this of their students.  I will require my child to do the same, regardless of whether or not a "law" is passed.  I'm surprised people would be so against it.  Just like the other guy mentioned the draft is just another form of community service that all men have to apply to.  I would think that if you aren't a soldier you should at least serve the community in another way.



You do realize that you get to choose how you serve the community.  It sounds like a lot of you haven't done community service before.  That's sad.



Source(s):



Required to do community service in high school.



</answer>

<answer from>
Member since: 27 April 2007
Total points: 7682 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



So far as I can tell it wouldn't be unconstitutional directly.  A law against abortion (I am just using the example and not trying to open that bag of worms) is not unconstitutional directly.  The Supreme Court determined it was unconstitutional by taking several amendments and using them to infer that there was an additional and unspecified right in the constitution called Privacy. Then they defined this new right to privacy as applying to a woman's body instead of to papers and effects and homes which actually was protected in the constitution even though they are not well protected now after the patriot act. Then they said laws against abortion were unconstitutional because they conflicted with the right to privacy which actually never existed before they decided it was there.  So this is how something that looks like it doesn't violate the constitution can end up doing it anyway. If they want to badly enough they can interpret the constitution to say pretty much anything they like by ignoring the idea that its a whole document with an intent and calling it a "living document" that must adjust to the times.



But all that aside the truth is that while it probably isn't unconstitutional, no politician would pass something like that because they wouldn't be re-elected. Actually the constitution might support the idea since it intended for states and cities to maintain militias which are a community service organization that would drill every week.  One concern is that for it to be constitutional it would have to apply to everyone.  You couldn't make just some people do community service arbitrarily as that would be unconstitutional.



</answer>

<answer from>



Sarah Louise Heath Palin
Member since: 11 April 2006
Total points: 2460 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



I am honored to be with you and with leaders from across this great country — leaders from different faiths and political parties united in a single voice of outrage.



Tomorrow, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad will come to New York — to the heart of what he calls the Great Satan — and speak freely in this, a country whose demise he has called for.



Ahmadinejad may choose his words carefully, but underneath all of the rhetoric is an agenda that threatens all who seek a safer and freer world. We gather here today to highlight the Iranian dictator's intentions and to call for action to thwart him.



He must be stopped.



The world must awake to the threat this man poses to all of us. Ahmadinejad denies that the Holocaust ever took place. He dreams of being an agent in a "Final Solution" — the elimination of the Jewish people. He has called Israel a "stinking corpse" that is "on its way to annihilation." Such talk cannot be dismissed as the ravings of a madman — not when Iran just this summer tested long-range Shahab-3 missiles capable of striking Tel Aviv, not when the Iranian nuclear program is nearing completion, and not when Iran sponsors terrorists that threaten and kill innocent people around the world.



The Iranian government wants nuclear weapons. The International Atomic Energy Agency reports that Iran is running at least 3,800 centrifuges and that its uranium enrichment capacity is rapidly improving. According to news reports, U.S. intelligence agencies believe the Iranians may have enough nuclear material to produce a bomb within a year.



The world has condemned these activities. The United Nations Security Council has demanded that Iran suspend its illegal nuclear enrichment activities. It has levied three rounds of sanctions. How has Ahmadinejad responded? With the declaration that the "Iranian nation would not retreat one iota" from its nuclear program.



So, what should we do about this growing threat? First, we must succeed in Iraq. If we fail there, it will jeopardize the democracy the Iraqis have worked so hard to build, and empower the extremists in neighboring Iran. Iran has armed and trained terrorists who have killed our soldiers in Iraq, and it is Iran that would benefit from an American defeat in Iraq.



If we retreat without leaving a stable Iraq, Iran's nuclear ambitions will be bolstered. If Iran acquires nuclear weapons — they could share them tomorrow with the terrorists they finance, arm, and train today. Iranian nuclear weapons would set off a dangerous regional nuclear arms race that would make all of us less safe.



But Iran is not only a regional threat; it threatens the entire world. It is the no. 1 state sponsor of terrorism. It sponsors the world's most vicious terrorist groups, Hamas and Hezbollah. Together, Iran and its terrorists are responsible for the deaths of Americans in Lebanon in the 1980s, in Saudi Arabia in the 1990s, and in Iraq today. They have murdered Iraqis, Lebanese, Palestinians, and other Muslims who have resisted Iran's desire to dominate the region. They have persecuted countless people simply because they are Jewish.



Iran is responsible for attacks not only on Israelis, but on Jews living as far away as Argentina. Anti-Semitism and Holocaust denial are part of Iran's official ideology and murder is part of its official policy. Not even Iranian citizens are safe from their government's threat to those who want to live, work, and worship in peace. Politically-motivated abductions, torture, death by stoning, flogging, and amputations are just some of its state-sanctioned punishments.



It is said that the measure of a country is the treatment of its most vulnerable citizens. By that standard, the Iranian government is both oppressive and barbaric. Under Ahmadinejad's rule, Iranian women are some of the most vulnerable citizens.



If an Iranian woman shows too much hair in public, she risks being beaten or killed.



If she walks down a public street in clothing that violates the state dress code, she could be arrested.



But in the face of this harsh regime, the Iranian women have shown courage. Despite threats to their lives and their families, Iranian women have sought better treatment through the "One Million Signatures Campaign Demanding Changes to Discriminatory Laws." The authorities have reacted with predictable barbarism. Last year, women's rights activist Delaram Ali was sentenced to 20 lashes and 10 months in prison for committing the crime of "propaganda against the system." After international protests, the judiciary reduced her sentence to "only" 10 lashes and 36 months in prison and then temporarily suspended her sentence. She still faces the threat of imprisonment.



Earlier this year, Senator Clinton said that "Iran is seeking nuclear weapons, and the Iranian Revolutionary Guard Corps is in the forefront of that" effort. Senator Clinton argued that part of our response must include stronger sanctions, including the designation of t



Source(s):



John McCain



</answer>

<question from>



Dave? Dave's not here
Member since: 15 September 2008
Total points: 760 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



What type of executive government job could I apply for with, lets say 143 days of experience in government?



You couldn't get a job at McDonalds and become district manager after 143 days of experience.



You couldn't become chief of surgery after 143 days of experience of being a surgeon.



You couldn't get a job as a t eacher and be the superintendent after 143 days of experience.



You couldn't join the military and become a colonel after a 143 days of experience.



You couldn't get a job as a reporter and become the nightly news anchor after 143 days of experience.



BUT....



'From the time Barack Obama was sworn in as a United State Senator, to the time he announced he was forming a Presidential exploratory committee, he logged 143 days of experience in the Senate. That's how many days the Senate was actually in session and working. After 143 days of work experience, Obama believed he was ready to be Commander In Chief, Leader of the Free World .... 143 days.



We all have to start somewhere. The senate is a good start, but after 143 days, that's all it is - a start.



AND, strangely, a large sector of the American public is okay with this and campaigning for him. We wouldn't accept this in our own line of work, yet some are okay with this for the President of the United States of America? Come on folks, we are not voting for the next American Idol!



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



You can apply for whatever job you want with whatever experience you have.  The employer will make a decision whether to hire you based on numerous factors.  Even at McDonald's.



</answer>

<answer from>



ruff-ruff grrrr
Member since: 27 December 2007
Total points: 1286 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



France's longest, closest, and most consistently enduring ally is America.  1773 - 1785.  The War of Independence.  America is fighting the British, and France shows up to help the American colonies.  Next come Spain and then the Dutch.  Not until after 1812 did England begin to accept the idea of a free nation called America.



France and England have had moments of peace in their times.  But they have also had far too many wars to be called long lasting allies.



So who now are France's allies?  You won't hear this uttered from the lips of a Frenchman anytime soon, but America still stands as their closest and biggest.



Enemies? From my lips to your ears, everybody in the world except Johnny Depp.  I direct you to this site for an example of their weenyness.



http://exchange.ydr.com/index.php?showto...

<original file>15880.html</original file>

<category>

</category>



<question from>



Marti C
Member since: 29 May 2008
Total points: 3053 (Level 4)



</question from>



<question>



Do you think you should have to pass a urine test to get govt assistance?



Why should govt money, which is my money, go to people who are on drugs?



</question>



<additional details>



Real Voter:  Why not?  Explain.



DJ Hartman, aren't we paying these people to do drugs? Aren't they supposed to be feeding their children?



</additional details>



<answer from>



Real Voter™
Member since: 21 May 2007
Total points: 10013 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Nope.



People choose to do what they want.  It's their choice.  Once you pay your taxes it is not up to you how they are spent.  They are no longer "your" tax dollars.



I think it is wrong for people who need assistance to be on drugs.  I also understand that part of the reason they need assistance might be that they are addicts.  Having been around addiction my whole life I feel some empathy.



I don't mind if poor people choose to do some things and make purchases which might bring them the slightest bit of joy in an otherwise incredibly stressful, dismal life.  I don't mind that someone on welfare carries a cell phone or even has a decent TV.  That's nothing compared to some of the enjoyments I can have in life.  Being poor does not mean one must be unhappy.  Again, this does not mean I support them doing drugs, but i view them as being no different than the rest of society.  Many middle and upper class people are on drugs, whether it be marijuana or prescription meds.  People are people.  Denying assistance to someone for failing a drug test will basically ensure that they will never make it to the next level.  There aren't sufficient programs in place to help every drug addict overcome their addiction.



This is not a simple issue.  There are no easy answers.



</answer>

<question>



Do you believe in Birth Control pills and Morning after pill? Or Just BC?



Okay, I am asking this question because it came up on the Colorado Ballot, about banning the Morning After Pill. The thing is that they are one in the same, but the morning after pill is just a stronger dose of BC.



Birth control pill can work in 3 ways to prevent pregnancy: 1. It will prevent ovulation 2. It will create a mucus that make it hard for sperm to go through the cervix 3. It prevents the zygote from connection to the uterus wall.



Morning after pill works in 2 ways to prevent pregnancy. 1. It will prevent ovulation 2. It prevents the zygote from connection to the uterus wall.



So, why do some people agree with BC, but not the morning after pill? Is it uneducated people? It is so easy to google. Please let me know how you feel on this topic. Thanks!



</question>

<question>



Prop 8, are you for or against and why? NO RELIGION PLEASE?



I was approached by 2 men from a church at my home a few weeks ago, they were trying to promote voting yes on prop 8, I told them I was agnostic and didn’t believe in passing laws based on the bible and “god’s word” they argued with me telling me atheism is a sin, then I made them feel REALLY stupid when I explained the difference between agnostic and atheist, I told them that I would give them my word to vote yes on prop 8 if they could give me ONE reason why prop 8 is going to ruin the country that DOES NOT involve ANY religion what-so-ever, bottom line is after a while of stumbling they could not give me a reason, especially when I told them that the divorce rate is ALREADY over 50% so why can’t the gays suffer like the rest of us? I told them that even though I don’t know much about the bible I know that god is supposed to love all of his “creatures” because he CREATED them so why would he hate his OWN creations? Once again, they had nothing relevant to say, I told them to please leave my doorstep and to maybe think about having an open mind and to stop hating and discriminating against people for their life choices especially since it does not affect them in any way shape or form, not to mention that prop 8 has nothing to do with teaching children about gay marriage, but don’t you think it’s a good idea to teach them young? Maybe if our children knew more about the subject we wouldn’t have gays and lesbians beat to death and discriminated on all around the country.



Why are the Jesus freaks so concerned about prop 8? How come it’s ok for a gay couple to be together for 13 years but it’s not ok for them to get married? Why is Jesus the one who says he loves all of his creatures yet these people are promoting hate and discrimination? Why can’t we just let people be? If we ban gay marriage we might as well start up slavery again right? We might as well open up some concentration camps and kill Jewish people again right? If we are going to hate and discriminate why only chose gays and lesbians? I think it’s so extremely unfair to treat people like this when they aren’t doing anything to hurt anyone, if they’ve been together for 20 years who cares if they marry? It’s not going to hurt me any!  I’m not gay, and I only know a few gay people but am not close to them and even I feel this is wrong, I would like to hear YOUR point of view on the subject WITHOUT ANY and I repeat ANY religious background.  I want to hear 2 sides, you’re for it and why, or you’re against it and why, if you’re against it please do not include ANYTHING based on religion or the bible, I want to see if there is ANYONE out there that can REALLY justify why we should blatantly discriminate against people for the way they were born.



If gay marriage is allowed to stay legal, how will it affect you financially? How will it affect ANY emotional or physical aspect of your life WITHOUT INCLUDING THE BIBLE, explain yourselves! I want to see how people think, but please if you are a crazy religious nut, please keep your ignorant bigotry at the door, or don’t answer at all.



</question>

<question from>



waterboy
Member since: 07 September 2007
Total points: 112 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Education is better than punishment in jail/prison system?



Debate class. I'm against it. I need help. What kind of arguments can i use to prove that education isn't better? i need about 4 arguments that can help me.



</question>



<answer from>



jellybea...
Member since: 08 July 2006
Total points: 21456 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Criminals don't deserve education.



Education doesn't punish.



People would commit crimes just so that they can go to jail and get an education.



Sorry, that's all I got.



</answer>



<answer from>



heyguy
Member since: 03 October 2008
Total points: 1809 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



A perfect combination of education and prison can be an effective use of reducing the relapse of criminals.



</answer>



<answer from>



uncle
Member since: 17 June 2008
Total points: 1770 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Punishment sends warning/signal of what is right(acceptable) and what is wrong(unacceptable) in society. Education can tell someone the rights and wrongs, but it doesn't ensure that everyone will abide by it.



Criminals should be given a 2nd chance, but only after they have realised their mistakes through some form of punishment eg. jail term.Sending them to school without further consequences may embolden them to commit more crimes since they can get away with the crimes easily with little punishment.



A fair education system educates. A fair punishment system also educates. Punishment in itself is an educational tool. Just as you can reward one for good behaviour, you should punish for bad behaviour.



Some hardcore criminals are a danger to society. Until they are reformed, confining them to jail would help ensure the safety of the general public.



</answer>



<answer from>



blindguy...
Member since: 17 September 2008
Total points: 3392 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



What you need are not "arguments. What you need are facts and figures.  Specifically: findings from studies conducted by social scientists and rehabilitation professionals that show that education, rather than punishment, correlates with  lower rates of repeat offenses.



You can find such studies in a variety of social science/psychology/education databases.  Any university has them--or use a school or library Internet portal to a university library database.



"Arguments" that aren't backed up by evidence are not arguments--they are unsupported opinion s and that is all they are.



Good luck to you!



</answer>

<answer from>



The Angry Sctotsman

<answer from>



Kirby S
Member since: 18 August 2008
Total points: 204 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



In all military technicality, yes, even the president, as Commander in Chief of the military, is expected to salute the flag.  The flag outranks everyone, even the president (though "flag" is not capitalized, as it is in your question).  Has Barack been schooled in military protocol?  He was a lawyer at Harvard, not a cadet at the USMA.  Has he failed to salute the flag at moments when you think he should have?  Well, he isn't president yet, and civilians do not (and are not expected to) salute the flag.  You must admit this, and gracefully accept my reproach.  Barack has done no wrong by not saluting the flag thus far because he is NOT Commander in Chief and to have saluted the flag as a senator would have been presumptuous and, frankly, rude.



Would you like to see him salute the flag whenever he passes it as president?  I think that would be neat.  Once he is president.  Not before.  Did George W. Bush always salute the flag?  Did you monitor him to see if he did?  Was he being unpatriotic whenever he didn't?  I get the feeling you don't care so much about what George did as you care about what Barack has not done to your satisfaction, even though what he has not done he was never supposed to do.



Civilians do not salute the flag.  Only people in the military do.  That is as it should be.  Presidents are in the military.  Barack is not president yet.  For him to salute the flag as a civilian would have been utterly ridiculous.



(Quick aside: as Commander in Chief, he is one of the few people not in uniform who may still correctly salute a flag-- MAY).



But as has already been said, this question is "old and boring."



Source(s):



Cadet from Norwich University...  I saluted the flag a lot, I know my Drill and Ceremony, I know the rules of "present arms" as well as anyone could.



</answer>

"that government is best which governs the least," what does "least" mean? It means that government should be rigidly limited to those functions that only the government can perform. Otherwise government will inevitably expand until it runs everything. That is why Thomas Jefferson described "a wise and frugal government, which shall restrain men from injuring one another, which shall leave them otherwise free to regulate their own pursuits of industry and improvement, and shall not take from the mouths of labor the bread it has earned."
